Consider the periods 1900–1920 and 1950–1970.
Which one of the following statements is supported by a comparison of the global surface temperature data for these periods?
There is too much variation in global surface temperature in each of the two periods to draw a conclusion that global surface temperatures are rising over time.
Within each 20-year period there was little overall change in global surface temperature. We can expect another period (2020-2040) to also have little overall change in temperature.

There are years after each of the two periods 1940–1945 and 1980–1985 when the global surface temperature shows little change. This suggests there is no real increase in global surface temperature over time.
The period 1950–1970 has a higher average global surface temperature than the period 1900–1920. This supports a hypothesis that global surface temperatures are increasing over time.
Two people are discussing the possible relationship between the two graphs.
Sharmin
Increasing surface temperature is the only cause of sea level rise.
Isabella
There are other factors besides surface temperature that are affecting sea level rise.
Explain how the data in the two graphs can be used to support Isabella’s opinion.
Which of the following reasons explain why is it useful to compare the data on global surface temperatures from the different sources?
Select all correct answers.
Groups of scientists rarely communicate with each other.
Differences in the data from each source for each year allow for error estimates.
Comparing the data from each source allows each group to identify and correct their measurements when errors are made.
Because the data from the sources differs, the accuracy of methods used can be judged.
